snippet.textDisplay:
That's what happens when you use most DANGEROUS way to travel for ordinary things in life. One little or 100 BIG, doesn't matter, every mistake results in death in Aviation.
Rich people takes risk thinking its a luxury while it's actually the opposite.
Kobe didn't had to use the heli. He wasn't in rush, he was retired and had time for his family. That's what happens when you push your luck in aviation. You get the worst of it at the end.

snippet.textDisplay: I have been wondering why he didn't fly over the ocean from Orange County airport to Thousand Oaks? You would have to deal with LAX ATC though. I have flown out of Orange County and Long Beach many times in helicopters. It only takes a minute or so to hit the beach. I usually would fly south to avoid all of the congestion to the north. I hate flying over LA congestion. There are so many homes, cars and people that if your aircraft has a problem you have no where to safely land in an emergency. I would take my chances over the ocean with the proper & approved ocean survival gear on board.
snippet.textOriginal: I have been wondering why he didn't fly over the ocean from Orange County airport to Thousand Oaks? You would have to deal with LAX ATC though. snippet.textDisplay: CAUSE OF CRASH:  The pilot was trying to fly as low as possible to stay below the overcast in poor visibility.  As the terrain started to rise along the 101 the pilot was forced to start climbing into the overcast which blocked all of his visibility and he lost sight of the ground and could no longer track the 101.  The helicopter flew south of the 101 before the pilot finally gave in and tried to turn around by attempting a 180 degree turn to the left while in complete instrument conditions.  In the turn, which could only be completed by flying on instruments, the pilot sped up and started descending trying to get back to lower ground so he could get back under the overcast and regain visual orientation.  Unfortunately, the pilot's horrifically poor judgement had put him in a position where he was flying completely blind, had lost track of where he was, and had no way of knowing where the terrain was.  He descended too soon, at too high of an airspeed, and struck a hill that he could not see or avoid.  Everyone died instantly.   What the pilot did was illegal and reckless, and a common cause of aircraft accidents.  All pilots are aware of this situation and are trained to avoid it.  A reasonable pilot exercising basic judgement would have landed at Van Nuys Airport, but this pilot continued on taking an unacceptable risk with the lives of his eight passengers.
snippet.textOriginal: CAUSE OF CRASH:  The pilot was trying to fly as low as possible to stay below the overcast in poor visibility.  As the terrain started to rise along the 101 the pilot was forced to start climbing into the overcast which blocked all of his visibility and he lost sight of the ground and could no longer track the 101.  The helicopter flew south of the 101 before the pilot finally gave in and tried to turn around by attempting a 180 degree turn to the left while in complete instrument conditions.  In the turn, which could only be completed by flying on instruments, the pilot sped up and started descending trying to get back to lower ground so he could get back under the overcast and regain visual orientation.  Unfortunately, the pilot's horrifically poor judgement had put him in a position where he was flying completely blind, had lost track of where he was, and had no way of knowing where the terrain was.  He descended too soon, at too high of an airspeed, and struck a hill that he could not see or avoid.  Everyone died instantly.   What the pilot did was illegal and reckless, and a common cause of aircraft accidents.  All pilots are aware of this situation and are trained to avoid it.  A reasonable pilot exercising basic judgement would have landed at Van Nuys Airport, but this pilot continued on taking an unacceptable risk with the lives of his eight passengers.

snippet.textDisplay: Perhaps after findings of NTSB's investigation, we're see real changes in helicopter safety. To begin with, the helicopter should never gotten permission to take off in such dense fog. 'Special VFR Clearance' procedures must be reviewed. The helicopter was flying much too low, after looping for 11 minutes in a holding patter, stuck between low clouds above and dense fog below - 'Special VFR Clearance' requires the  pilot to stay below 2,500 feet. Listening to the air traffic control audio, the pilot changed frequency at least 3 times. The last moments of communications were very weak and finally unintelligible. We'll never know if the pilot received the transmission notifying him that he was flying too low. RIP Kobe.
snippet.textOriginal: Perhaps after findings of NTSB's investigation, we're see real changes in helicopter safety. To begin with, the helicopter should never gotten permission to take off in such dense fog. 'Special VFR Clearance' procedures must be reviewed. The helicopter was flying much too low, after looping for 11 minutes in a holding patter, stuck between low clouds above and dense fog below - 'Special VFR Clearance' requires the  pilot to stay below 2,500 feet. Listening to the air traffic control audio, the pilot changed frequency at least 3 times. The last moments of communications were very weak and finally unintelligible. We'll never know if the pilot received the transmission notifying him that he was flying too low. RIP Kobe.

snippet.textDisplay:
Great investigative reporting, as usual, thanks "failing" NYT.
The FAA should mandate terrain alert crash warning for all helicopter a long time ago -- shame on them https://www.latimes.com/california/story/2020-01-30/kobe-bryants-helicopter-didnt-have-terrain-alert-system-would-it-have-made-a-difference
Additionally black boxes should be considered the overhead cost of doing business for all helicopters -- again shame on the FAA.
Both of these should have been implemented years ago. FAA -- do your job.

snippet.textDisplay: That diagram of trajectory of crash path doesn't look accurate. The helicopter went from 2,300 feet to 1,000 feet (crash site) in less than 15 seconds. That's a dramatic fall not this gradual loss of altitude shown on topographic image.
snippet.textOriginal: That diagram of trajectory of crash path doesn't look accurate. The helicopter went from 2,300 feet to 1,000 feet (crash site) in less than 15 seconds. That's a dramatic fall not this gradual loss of altitude shown on topographic image.

snippet.textDisplay: Interesting. The audio they released a few days ago doesn’t include the pilot saying anything about claiming to 2200 to avoid anything. So when they say that „it missed clearing the tip by 20-30 feet“, do they mean it hit somewhere at the middle of that? If he was higher than the hill top just seconds before, why would the aircraft quickly drive into the side of the hill?
snippet.textOriginal: Interesting. The audio they released a few days ago doesn’t include the pilot saying anything about claiming to 2200 to avoid anything. snippet.textDisplay: If you are familiar with OC/LA you'll know this isn't that far of a drive. Sunday morning is the best day of the week as well due to very few cars on the road. I really don't understand traveling this way on a Sunday. Could even be faster to drive to Mamba after factoring in times to and from airports. I grew up near the beach near here. Choppers never fly in fog that thick.

snippet.textDisplay:
Thank you for clarifying that it was not foggy from where they boarded the helicopter. Seems stupid of me now, but I assumed it was foggy the whole time & that Kobe had made the decision to fly in it despite the fog.

He didn’t know the weather was going to change— it seems to me now that that particular flight was simply ill-fatedly doomed.

The pilot probably panicked after ascending so high so quickly—it was like he was blindfolded. People become paralyzed we lose our confidence when we can’t see.
snippet.textOriginal:
Thank you for clarifying that it was not foggy from where they boarded the helicopter. Seems stupid of me now, but I assumed it was foggy the whole time & that Kobe had made the decision to fly in it despite the fog. 

He didn’t know the weather was going to change— it seems to me now that that particular flight was simply ill-fatedly doomed.

The pilot probably panicked after ascending so high so quickly—it was like he was blindfolded. People become paralyzed we lose our confidence when we can’t see.

snippet.textDisplay: the NTSB has given the reason and how to prevent this crash for years and the FAA will not enforce the recommendation that helicopters be equipped with A Terrain Avoidance and Warning System (TAWS) .August 27, 1990 SRV died due to helicopter crashing into hillside in low visibility

snippet.textDisplay: Shame on you NYT! "investigators said the helicopter may have missed clearing the top of the hill by 20 to 30 feet" Sensationalism to profit from tragedy! Investigators also said, "if they had cleared the hill, the helicopter would have faced many more ahead" This wasn't a situation of almost making it, the copter fell 1000 feet suddenly.
snippet.textOriginal: Shame on you NYT! _"investigators said the helicopter may have missed clearing the top of the hill by 20 to 30 feet"_   Sensationalism to profit from tragedy! Investigators also said, _"if they had cleared the hill, the helicopter would have faced many more ahead"_ This wasn't a situation of almost making it, the copter fell 1000 feet suddenly.

snippet.textDisplay: The pilot never directly requested flight following by radar; earlier, it was asked of him if he wanted it-he replied yes. If that controller never asked him for it, perhaps he wouldn't have tried to rise up so soon.

snippet.textDisplay: 1st.sequence. of this event  happen while holding over Glendale waiting to go through class C airspace at Burbank airport ATC noted why the delay of the hold for 15 min. 2nd sequence. "(got-to-get-their-itis") 3rd.sequence. was because at Van Nuys airport is encountering ("Multiple IFR departures waiting") thus the the hold... 4th.sequence. this should have been indicator to the PIC that in that airspace close to their destination was experiencing IMC issues a foot...thus to fly through that airspace to the destination would request a special emergency IFR while still flying his special VFR clearance...he had to maintain the special VFR  and could not pop up to a higher AGL with out permission from ATC less running into other flying IFR above the aircraft...this has been a killer for years... The FAA rule is that PIC can fly  VFR with 2 mile visibility all day long...BIRDS WILL FALL OUT with such overcast yet we humans can fly with such low visibility at 200 miles per hour...they must change that ruling it killing us yet they call it safe... its an understand that  ATC only makes suggestion to PIC they can't make the PIC do things... however in this case Van Nuys should advise Burbank ATC that traffic coming into their airspace need to be using IFR and suggest all VFR would be at the PIC risk that would be a fair warning to Special VFR ... no such warning ATC ever makes... in fact ATC is limited because of their governing body the FAA that runs the show. this issue of flying VFR into IMC needs a ruling ASAP before more of us die... How many of us must die before a change must take place...Kobe would be alive today if their was a ruling on VFR flying done Years ago... let write congress and ask for the FAA to get on a move in shifting this paradigm... My condolences to the Bryant Family to the PIC his family and all who died needlessly
snippet.textOriginal: 1st.sequence. of this event  happen while holding over Glendale waiting to go through class C airspace at Burbank airport ATC noted why the delay of the hold for 15 min. 2nd sequence. "(got-to-get-their-itis") 3rd.sequence. was because at Van Nuys airport is encountering ("Multiple IFR departures waiting") thus the the hold... 4th.sequence. this should have been indicator to the PIC that in that airspace close to their destination was experiencing IMC issues a foot...thus to fly through that airspace to the destination would request a special emergency IFR while still flying his special VFR clearance...he had to maintain the special VFR  and could not pop up to a higher AGL with out permission from ATC less running into other flying IFR above the aircraft...this has been a killer for years... The FAA rule is that PIC can fly  VFR with 2 mile visibility all day long...BIRDS WILL FALL OUT with such overcast yet we humans can fly with such low visibility at 200 miles per hour...they must change that ruling it killing us yet they call it safe... its an understand that  ATC only makes suggestion to PIC they can't make the PIC do things... however in this case Van Nuys should advise Burbank ATC that traffic coming into their airspace need to be using IFR and suggest all VFR would be at the PIC risk that would be a fair warning to Special VFR ... no such warning ATC ever makes... in fact ATC is limited because of their governing body the FAA that runs the show. this issue of flying VFR into IMC needs a ruling ASAP before more of us die... How many of us must die before a change must take place...Kobe would be alive today if their was a ruling on VFR flying done Years ago... let write congress and ask for the FAA to get on a move in shifting this paradigm... My condolences to the Bryant Family to the PIC his family and all who died needlessly

snippet.textDisplay: Other pilots who know the area are saying it may not have mattered if they cleared that ridge, as there are many ridges beyond it. Should be illegal to fly children in an ill-equipped aircraft, not to mention putting children on the ground at risk. Tragic. RIP
